descriptions.description: High-quality software with more features enhances the project's public perception and credibility.
A larger user base provides more testimonials and visibility, which bolsters the project's reputation.
More core developers increases the total workload for reviews, potentially slowing down the process.
Longer review delays mean more time is available to provide detailed, constructive feedback.
A larger backlog of pull requests under review generates a greater volume of feedback activity.
A rich base of implicit knowledge provides more material for experienced members to share via mentorship.
More core developers increases the capacity for one-on-one mentorship and implicit knowledge transfer.
Timely and helpful feedback encourages newcomers to stay and formally join the contributor community.
Constructive feedback helps experienced contributors refine their skills and solidify their role.
Positive feedback and successful contributions are a key pathway for promoting contributors to core developers.
New contributors actively participate in discussions, asking questions and generating feedback loops.
Experienced contributors provide more frequent and higher-quality feedback on pull requests.
The process of giving and receiving feedback keeps pull requests in an active, reviewed state.
Well-documented explicit knowledge makes it easier to create guides and onboard new contributors.
Feedback from code reviews contains valuable insights that are archived into the knowledge base.
Resolved issues provide solutions and patterns that are documented in the searchable knowledge base.
A comprehensive knowledge base directly expands the project's repository of explicit, documented knowledge.
Community discussions generate questions, answers, and decisions that enrich the knowledge base.
A strong reputation attracts more users to adopt and try the software.
A high number of open issues prompts more user and developer comments, questions, and feedback.
Active feedback on issues often reveals new aspects or problems, leading to more open issues.
A healthy, collaborative community is a positive signal that enhances the project's overall reputation.
Good documentation lowers the barrier to entry, making it easier for new contributors to join.
A clear and fair governance strategy makes the project more attractive for potential contributors to join.
An effective governance strategy encourages participation, increasing the rate of new contributors joining.
A project with a high reputation attracts more developers who want to contribute and be associated with it.
More time dedicated by maintainers allows for a faster rate of identifying, fixing, and closing issues.
As issues are resolved, they are moved from the open state to the closed state, increasing the stock.
The ongoing creation of new issues adds to the stock of open, unresolved problems.
Faster issue resolution depletes the backlog of open issues, reducing the stock.
A larger and more complex codebase provides more surface area for bugs and feature requests, generating more issues.
Positive project activities and outcomes accumulate over time, building up the project's reputation.
Negative events or stagnation gradually erode the project's standing and perceived value.
As documented knowledge is internalized by contributors, it becomes implicit, reducing the explicit stock.
The act of codifying new discoveries and practices adds to the repository of explicit knowledge.
New users adopting the software increase the total user base.
Users leaving or stopping their use of the software decrease the total user base.
Merging or committing a pull request removes it from the 'under review' queue.
Rejecting a pull request removes it from the 'under review' queue without merging.
Initiating a review on a new pull request moves it into the 'under review' stock.
Merging a pull request integrates new code into the main codebase, increasing its size and functionality.
Access to good documentation accelerates the learning process and skill development for contributors.
Direct mentorship transfers tacit knowledge quickly, accelerating a contributor's skill development.
Active community engagement in forums and chats produces content that is added to the knowledge base.
Open issues represent work to be done, inspiring contributors to submit pull requests as solutions.
The submission of new pull requests adds to the stock of contributions awaiting initial review.
When a review starts, the pull request moves from 'new' to 'under review', reducing this stock.
Core developers leaving the project reduces the number of experienced maintainers.
Promoting experienced contributors to core developer status increases the core team size.
Effective mentorship prepares and qualifies experienced contributors for promotion to core developers.
When developers leave, they take their unique, unrecorded knowledge with them, causing a loss.
Promoting an experienced contributor to core developer moves them out of the experienced contributor stock.
As new contributors develop their skills, they graduate into the experienced contributor stock.
New contributors joining the project increases the pool of novice developers.
As new contributors skill up, they graduate out of the 'new' category into experienced contributors.
The departure of experienced developers depletes the project's collective tacit knowledge.
As contributors internalize documented knowledge, it becomes part of the team's implicit know-how.
The process of formally codifying implicit knowledge removes it from the tacit knowledge stock.
Negative interactions and burnout degrade the collaborative spirit and well-being of the community.
Positive interactions and reliable collaboration build mutual respect and a healthier community.
